Award.AwardTitle: California State University Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (CSU-LSAMP) Senior Alliance (2013-2018)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a continuation of the NSF-supported California State University-Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (CSU-LSAMP). Initiated in 1993-1994, CSU-LSAMP is an alliance of the 23 campuses of the California State University (CSU) system, which supports a coordinated and comprehensive system-wide approach to broadening participation in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. CSU-LSAMP's overall goal for the project is to contribute to the development of a STEM workforce, which is broadly inclusive, globally competitive, and prepared to participate at the frontiers of science. Specifically, CSU-LSAMP aims to:
a)Enhance the academic and professional preparation of CSU-LSAMP participants, most of whom are students from underrepresented minorities (URM), for careers in STEM.
b)Further improve persistence and graduation rates for CSU-LSAMP participants.
c)Increase aggregate production of STEM degrees awarded by the CSU to URM students.
d)Increase the number of CSU-LSAMP students who advance to STEM graduate study.
e)Document, disseminate, and replicate undergraduate intervention models that increase access to, and success in STEM baccalaureate degree programs and facilitate admissions to STEM graduate programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Description: The California State University Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (CSU-LSAMP) was initiated in 1994 to serve as a comprehensive, statewide program dedicated to broadening participation in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) programs. The alliance includes all 23 campuses of the California State University, the largest university system of public higher education in the world, located in one of the most populous and diverse states in the nation. CSU-LSAMP's goals for this project period were to (1) enhance the academic and professional preparation of CSU-LSAMP participants, most of whom are students from underrepresented minorities (URM), for careers in STEM; (2) further improve persistence and graduation rates for CSU-LSAMP participants; (3) increase aggregate production of STEM degrees awarded by the CSU to URM students; (4) increase the number of CSU-LSAMP students who advance to STEM graduate study; and (5) document, disseminate, and replicate undergraduate intervention models that increase access to, and success in STEM baccalaureate degree programs and facilitate admissions to STEM graduate programs.

Project Activities: CSU-LSAMP serves students through activities that support academic preparation and professional development as well as develop a sense of community and belonging. To accommodate the differences of our 23 campuses and better leverage existing programs, we adopted an approach that provides campuses with flexibility in determining the types of activities they offer. Campuses identify as having one of three emphases: Academic Preparation and Persistence; Professional Preparation; and Dual Emphasis. Campuses with an emphasis in Academic Preparation provide activities such as supplemental learning, summer bridge programs, and textbook support. Campuses with an emphasis on Professional Preparation offer activities such as research, international research, and travel professional conferences. Dual Emphasis campuses offer the full range of activities. All campuses are expected to offer community-building activities.

Project Outcomes: Since its inception, CSU-LSAMP has served over 25,000 students, most of whom are from underrepresented minority groups. For the current project period, CSU-LSAMP served over 3,000 students per year, including approximately 800 per year in supplemental instruction, 900 per year in research, and 45 per year in international research activities. Since the start of this project period, URM enrollment in STEM in the CSU has increased by 138% and the number of STEM baccalaureate degrees awarded to URM students by the CSU has more than doubled. CSU-LSAMP participants have published their research in peer-reviewed journals and presented their research at international, national, and regional professional conferences. Underrepresented minorities who participate in our program show significantly higher retention and graduation rates when compared with URM students who do not participate in LSAMP and indeed, show retention and graduation rates that are comparable with those for non-URM students. Over 40% of CSU-LSAMP participants continue on to graduate programs in STEM, with 500 graduates entering programs each year. CSU-LSAMP has therefore made significant progress in closing the achievement gap for underrepresented minorities in STEM and successfully increased the diversity of students moving into graduate programs in STEM.

 


Last Modified: 10/22/2018
Modified by: Lisa C Hammersley
